thread.title: ‘He can beat anyone in the country at 90kg’
thread.title_full: ‘He can beat anyone in the country at 90kg’

title: ‘He can beat anyone in the country at 90kg’
text:
Queensland Reds ban Quade Cooper from fighting in kickboxing tag-team bout  37pm by Grantlee Kieza Source: The Courier-Mail QUADE Cooper’s boxing coach would love to partner the rugby star in the new concept of tag-team fighting but the Reds will not let their playmaker be kicked in the legs. 
Shaggy King, a former Australian boxing champ and star of the international Muay Thai circuit, has been coaching Cooper in fighting for four years and is introducing a new concept to his sold-out Thai boxing shows at the Bowen Hills YMCA. 
Last seen across Australia slugging it out on a huge program of boxing telecast by Channel 9 in November 2015, King is back using his legs in his first love on Saturday night. 
He will partner another Brisbane headkicker, Jamie Fleming, in his tag-team concept on a card featuring 12 fights. Quade Cooper copped plenty of flak for fighting Jack McInnes. Source: AAP 
“Quade Cooper is a terrific boxer but he only wants to throw punches,’’ said King, who shows no signs of slowing down at 39. 
“Because of his rugby he won’t risk anything happening to his legs. 
“I really think he has the potential to be a champion boxer. He loves it. If I could train him in boxing for a year straight he would beat anyone in the country at 90kg. 
INEXPERIENCE: Cooper admits he’s still green as a fighter 
“He’s going to train with me all through the rugby season and we’ve seen in the past when Quade does a lot of boxing training the fitness and the discipline really makes him perform well on the field.’’ 
King, who won the Australian 70kg boxing title in 2013 and lost it in the Channel 9 thriller against Rocky Jerkic, said he had introduced tag-team kickboxing as a way of keeping his first sport fresh and exciting. Cooper lands a stiff jab on McInnes. Picture: Sarah Reed Source: News Corp Australia 
“The crowds love it,’’ he said. “It adds another level of excitement and it will be another sold out show on Saturday. 
“We are able to try the concept because Queensland is the only state that doesn’t have a proper state-run combat commission so we are able to experiment with the rules. 
“We’ve got promoters coming over from Thailand to see how it looks and they’re interested in trying tag-team at their fights in Bangkok.’’ 
The tag-team concept allows a hurt fighter to swap places with a fresh replacement who takes over the fighting for him. 
King’s Corporate Gym headquarters in Lutwyche is the busiest fighting gym in Australia, last year producing contestants for 278 bouts in boxing, Thai boxing and mixed martial arts. 
Cooper has had three boxing matches for three quick KO wins against outgunned opponents. King wants to step up the level of competition after a break in Cooper’s rugby commitments at the end of the season.
